Fig. 11 Crystal-facet dependent CO oxidation, preferential oxidation of CO in H2-rich, water-gas shift reactions, and supercapacitor application over Co3O4 nanostructures Young In Choi Hee Jung Yoon Seog K. Kim Youngku Sohn ⁎ School of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Yeungnam University, Gyeongsan, Gyeongbuk 38541, South Korea, South Korea School of Chemistry and Biochemistry Yeungnam University Gyeongsan Gyeongbuk 38541 South Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Tailoring the exposed crystal facet of a material is a very important strategy for improving the application performance. Herein, cubic phase Co3O4 with two different morphologies, nanoplates and nanologs, was synthesized, and CO oxidation, preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) under H2-rich condition, water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, and supercapacitor properties were examined. The nanoplates with {112}-exposed facets showed better performance in all the test model systems. The {112} facets contained more active Co3+, which is responsible for the activation of CO oxidation (and H2 production) at a lower temperatures. A facial ion transport on the facet increased the specific capacitance of the plates. The wider application tests and the design of Co oxide nanostructures provide a better strategy for the development of Co-based materials. Keywords Co3O4 CO oxidation Preferential oxidation of CO Water-gas shift reaction Supercapacitor 1 Introduction Understanding the performance of crystal facet-dependent catalytic reactions and the corresponding crystal phase changes is very important for developing efficient catalyst materials [1–3]. Among the many transition metal oxide materials, cobalt oxides are indispensable for a wide range of applications, such as energy/environment catalysts and electrodes (e.g., supercapacitors and batteries) [4–32]. Persisting efforts have been devoted to tailoring the morphology of Co oxide materials [4–32]. A wide range of methods have been used to produce various morphologies; sub-3nm films [9], nanocubes [26], nanospheres [16,18], nanorods/nanowires [7,27–30], nanoplates/nanosheets [14,31,32], nanotubes [15], hollow structures [16–18], hierarchical, (meso)porous [8,19–21], nanochains [22], nanoporous walls [23], and multi-shelled [24]. Co3O4 has mixed oxidation states of Co2+ and Co3+, and Co3+ has been reported to be more active than Co2+ for CO adsorption and oxidation [7,23]. For this reason, the catalytic activity is strongly dependent on the morphology (or the amount of exposed Co3+ on the surface) [1,15,34]. Various catalytic activity tests using Co3O4 have been reported, including CO oxidation [7,8,26–28,35,36], low temperature propane oxidation [11,37], CO hydrogenation [38], preferential CO oxidation [33], electrochemical water splitting [39], oxygen reduction reaction [22,30,40], H2O2 oxidation [18], HCHO oxidation [41], water oxidation [20,42–44], methane combustion [6,15], and organic pollutants treatments [45]. CO oxidation over Co3O4 has been studied extensively because of its significantly high oxidation activity at low temperatures [8,21,27,28,35]. Xie et al. reported that predominantly {110} facet-exposed Co3O4 nanorods exhibited CO oxidation activity at liquid nitrogen temperature, which was attributed to the larger amounts (or a higher Co3+/Co2+ ratio) of exposed active Co3+ [7,21]. Mesoporous Co3O4 nanostructures exhibited enhanced catalytic activity in CO oxidation [3,8], as well as oxygen evolution [20]. The crystal facet-dependent methane combustion activities were reported for Co3O4 nanosheets, nanobelts and nanocubes prepared by a hydrothermal method. The catalytic activity on the crystal facet was found to be {112}>{011}>> {001} [6]. Zheng et al. recently reported the photo-/thermo-catalytic (propylene and propane oxidation) activity of ultrathin mesoporous CO3O4 nanosheets on a stainless steel mesh prepared using an electrochemical deposition method [4]. CO is present as an impurity in H2 gas produced by a WGS reaction. For this reaction, the purification of hydrogen is essential to eliminate CO poisoning in a fuel cell, such as the proton exchange membrane fuel cell (PEMFC) anode [33]. For this purpose, the preferential oxidation (PROX) of CO in H2 has been demonstrated. Nguyen et al. prepared surface-oxygen vacancy induced CO3O4-x and reported 100% conversion of CO in H2 at 120°C for continuously over a 96h period [33]. Applications to an energy storage system, such as supercapacitors and batteries, have also been demonstrated using CO3O4 with a range of morphologies to obtain the practical performance and better stability [9,31,32,46–51]. Feng et al. reported that sub-3nm atomic layers CO3O4 nanofilms showed an ultrahigh specific capacitance of 1400F/g and only a 3% decrease in capacitance after a cycling test for 1500 cycles [9]. Gao et al. prepared (001) plane-exposed CO3O4 cubes and (111) plane-exposed octahedrons, tested for the Li−O2 battery cathode, and reported that the octahedron showed much higher electrocatalytic performance, such as the oxygen evolution reaction, charge/discharge capacity and rate capability, which was attributed to the richer Co2+ and active sites [48]. Motivated by the above-mentioned applications, this paper reports Co3O4 nanostructures with two different morphologies, nanoplates and nanologs, for various applications, such as the WGS reaction for H2-production, preferential CO oxidation for H2-purification by removing residual CO impurity, CO oxidation for a clean environment, and supercapacitor applications for energy storage and electrodes. Many literatures have showed narrow application of a synthesized material. The novelty of the present study is that we have performed diverse applications to examine the facet-dependent activities on various applications of a synthesized material. Direct comparison of Co3O4 catalysts for the diverse applications was not readily available so far. This motivates us to collect big data and directly compare their relative facet-dependent catalytic activities for the diverse applications. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Synthesis of Co3O4 nanostructures Co3O4 nanostructures with two different morphologies were synthesized as follows. For one morphology (designated as P), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (1.0mmol) was dissolved completely in a mixed (20mL of H2O+10mL of ethanol) solvent. Subsequently, 1.0mL of dimethylamine and 1.0mL of oleic acid were added to the solution. This was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept in an oven at 180°C for 12h. After the reaction, the solution was cooled naturally to room temperature and the powder sample (with violet color) was collected, washed completely and dried at 80°C. For the other morphology (designated as L), 0.27g of oxalic acid was used instead of the dimethylamine and oleic acid. The other conditions were kept constant. The as-prepared dried samples were then annealed thermally at 350°C for 3h to finally obtain Co3O4 nanostructures. The two annealed samples were designated Pan and Lan. Ag nanoparticles were loaded unto the Co3O4 nanostructures by a photoreduction method. The powder samples was first dispersed in water (containing 1mol% Ag ions relative to Co3O4) and irradiated with UV light for 2h. 2.2 Characterization of Co3O4 nanostructures The characterization of the surface morphology was examined by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800) with an operation acceleration voltage of 5–20keV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM, Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN) images of the Co3O4 nanostructures were recorded using at an acceleration voltage of 200kV. The powder samples were mounted on a carbon-coated Cu grid by dropping a powder-dispersed ethanol solution followed by drying in air. X-ray diffraction (XRD PANalytical X’Pert Pro MPD) was performed to examine the crystal phase of the powder samples using a diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (40kV and 30mA). XPS was performed using a Thermo-VG Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with a monochromated Al Kα X-ray source (E=1486.6eV) and a hemispherical energy analyzer. 2.3 CO oxidation, PROX of CO in H2-rich condition, and WGS reaction The CO oxidation activity over the Co3O4 nanostructures was measured in a quartz U-tube with 20mg of the powder samples. The experiment was conducted in a CO(1.0%)/O2(2.5%)/N2 gas mixture with a flow rate of 40mL/min. The gas products were monitored according to the reaction temperature using a RGA200 mass spectrometer (Stanford Research Systems). For the preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX), 5% H2/N2 gas with the CO oxidation gas mixture was also introduced, with an oxygen excess factor (λ) of 5.0. The other catalytic test conditions were the same as the CO oxidation. For the water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, H2O vapor and CO gas were introduced by purging 5% CO/N2 gas through deionized water into the sample. The samples were designated PCO and LCO after CO oxidation, PPROX and LPROX after the preferential oxidation of CO, and PWGS and LWGS after the water-gas shift reactions. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments under a 5% H2/N2 gas flow were performed using a ChemBET TPR/TPD analyzer (Quantachrome Instruments) at a heating ramp rate of 20°C/min (up to 900°C) at a flow rate of 40mL/min. 2.4 Electrochemical and supercapacitor tests A typical three-electrode system was used to examine the electrochemical properties of the powder samples. A Pt wire (counter electrode), Ag/AgCl reference electrode and a working electrode in a 6.0M KOH aqueous solution were connected electrically to a CHI660D electrochemical work station (CH Instruments, Austin, USA) at room temperature. The working electrode was prepared as follows. The active Co3O4 materials, acetylene black and poly(vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) with a weight ratio of 60%:20%:20% were first mixed fully in 2mL of N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) solvent. The solution was dropped into Ni foam (1cm×1cm), fully dried and pressed to make a thin sheet (working electrode). The galvanostatic charge-discharge experiment was performed over the potential range, −0.2 to 0.5V with different charge densities. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed over the frequency range, 0.1MHz to 0.01Hz. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and crystal structures The morphology can be controlled by a simple hydrothermal method using different surfactants, and two different morphologies are presented. Fig. 1 shows SEM images of the two (Pan and Lan) annealed samples in black. The samples exhibited strong UV and visible absorption (Supporting information, Fig. S1). The two samples showed critically different morphologies. One exhibited hexagonal (smooth vertexes) nanoplates (or nanosheets) with widths of 200∼300nm. The plates were measured to be 20–30nm thick. A Co precursor with a nanosheet morphology was Co(OH)2, which was transformed to a Co3O4 nanosheet after a thermal treatment [6]. The other morphology had the appearance of wooden logs, whose sizes were estimated to be 2∼10μm. The logs appeared to an assembly of small particles. The Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) surface areas were 27.7 and 31.4m2/g for the plates and logs, respectively. The surface area of the logs was somewhat larger due to the assembly of smaller particles for the logs. For comparison, the surface areas of Co3O4 cubes (∼500nm) and octahedra (∼700nm) were reported to be 3.44 and 1.83m2/g, respectively [48]. Fig. 2 presents XRD patterns of the as-prepared and 350°C-annealed samples. The as-prepared samples showed critically different XRD patterns while the annealed samples showed the same patterns. (also see Supporting information., Fig. S2) For the as-prepared nanoplates (Pas), the XRD patterns (●) matched those of hexagonal (P-3m1) cobalt hydroxide, Co(OH)2 (JCPDS 98-008-8940) [31]. The dominant peak at 2θ=19.1° was assigned to the (001) plane of the hexagonal phase. For the as-prepared sample with a nanolog morphology (Las), the XRD patterns (☆) became more complicated. The patterns matched those of monoclinic (C12/c1) cobalt oxalate dihydrate, C2CoO4·2H2O (JCPDS 98-015-0589). The first two peaks at 2θ=18.7° and 18.9° corresponded to the (200) and (110) planes of the crystal structure. After annealing the two different samples (Pan and Lan) to 350°C, the two different XRD patterns changed to the same XRD patterns. The XRD peak positions were in good accordance with those of the cubic (Fd-3m) phase Co3O4 (JCPDS 98-003-6256). A dominant XRD peak at 2θ=36.9° was attributed to the (311) plane of the cubic phase Co3O4. The other peaks at 2θ=19.0°, 31.2°, 38.6°, 44.9°, 55.7°, 59.4°, and 65.3° were assigned to the (111), (220), (222), (400), (422), (511), and (440) planes, respectively. The XRD peaks of the annealed nanologs (Lan) were stronger than those of the annealed nanoplates (Pan), which is indicative of high crystallinity. 3.2 Microstructures Fig. 3 shows TEM and HRTEM images of the Co3O4 plates and logs. The sizes of the plates and the logs were a few μm, as observed in the SEM images. In the HRTEM image of a plate, a clear fringe spacing was found to be 0.288nm, which corresponded to the (220) planes of cubic phase Co3O4. The {112} facet is normal to the (220) plane (or the (222) plane with a lattice spacing of 0.23nm). Therefore, the major exposed planes for the nanosheets are {112} facet, which is in good agreement with the literature [6,9,15,50]. For the HRTEM image of the logs, a clear lattice fringe was found to be 0.248nm, corresponding to the (311) plane. The corresponding FFT patterns indicated the high crystalline nature of the plates and logs. 3.3 Surface chemical states The surface chemical states of the two different samples were examined by XPS. Fig. 4 shows the corresponding Co 2p, O 1s and survey XPS spectra (Supporting information, Fig. S3). The survey spectrum dominantly shows the elements of Co and O from Co3O4. The C 1s XPS peak at 285.0eV was attributed to impurity carbon present on the surface. No other elements were found. The Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 XPS peaks were commonly observed at 779.7 and 794.8eV, respectively, with a spin-orbit splitting of 15.1eV, which is in good consistent with the literature for mixed-valence Co3O4 [4,8,17,21,37,52]. Two resolved Co 2p peaks (Supporting information., Fig. S4) clearly indicate the coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+, which is in good agreement with the mixed oxidation states (2+ and 3+) of Co3O4 [9,27,30,44]. The two oxidation states were confirmed by the Co LMM Auger line (Supporting information., Fig. S5). The coexistence was also confirmed by the corresponding FT-IR spectra, as discussed below. The strong/broad satellite peaks at 789 and 805eV confirmed the presence of Co2+ [52]. The satellite peaks were somewhat stronger for the nanologs. Based on the surface sensitive XPS results for the nanologs, Co2+ is more exposed than Co3+ on the surface, i.e., the nanoplates contained more exposed Co3+ on the surface. It was reported that Co3+ was more active than Co2+ for CO adsorption and oxidation [7,23]. This is in good consistent with the enhanced catalytic activity for the nanoplates, further discussed below. For the corresponding O 1s XPS peaks, two peaks were commonly observed. The major peak at 529.8eV (or 529.9eV) was attributed to lattice Co-O, and the minor peak at 531.6eV was due to the chemisorbed OH and/or oxygen vacancies (O− and O2 −) [4,22,37]. The tailed O 1s peak at approximately 533eV was attributed to adsorbed water. For the nanoplates, the lattice oxygen and other oxygen species were found to be 63.4 and 36.6%, respectively (Supporting information., Fig. S6). For the nanologs, the lattice oxygen and other oxygen species were found to be 61.4 and 38.5%, respectively. The O 1s peak at 531.6eV for the nanoplates was somewhat weaker than that for the nanologs. In other words, Lewis acidic Co2+/Co3+ ions were more exposed on the nanoplate surface. The atomic concentrations (%) of Co and O were determined by XPS. For the nanoplates and the nanologs, Co(%)/O(%) ratios were determined to be 38.8%/61.2% (or Co1O1.58) and 35.3%/64.7% (or Co1O1.83), respectively. The observed oxygen concentrations were somewhat larger, compared with the theoretical concentration of 42.9%/57.1% (or Co1O1.33) for Co3O4. This was due to adsorbed oxygen species. By comparing the two relative values of Co1O1.58 and Co1O1.83, it could be concluded that active Co ions were more exposed on the surface of the nanoplates than of the nanologs. The more Lewis acidic species are exposed on the surface the more Lewis basic species (such as CO) are possibly reacted. Based on this, the higher Co ion density could be an origin of the enhanced catalytic activity of the nanoplates for CO oxidation, CO-PROX and WGSR [53]. In the FT-IR spectrum (Supporting information., Fig. S7), the OH stretching band (at 3400cm−1) for the nanologs was stronger than that for the nanoplates, which is consistent with the O 1s XPS result [8]. Two strong FT-IR bands were observed at 555 and 655cm−1, which were assigned to the Co(II,III)-O stretching vibrations for Co3+ with tetrahedral coordination and Co2+ with octahedral coordination, respectively [10,17,37,43]. For the nanologs with a porous structure, shoulder FT-IR peaks were also observed near the two peaks, which were attributed to Co inside and outside the structures. 3.4 CO oxidation activity CO oxidation reaction was performed for the Co3O4 nanoplates and nanologs. Fig. 5 presents the first and second run CO conversion (%) profiles with the reaction temperature. For the first run, the CO oxidation reaction began to appear at approximately 70°C and 150°C for the plates and logs, respectively. The T10% (°C) (the temperature at 10% CO conversion) [54–60] was observed at 130°C and 160°C, respectively. In the second run, T10%(°C) was observed at 100°C and 150°C for the plates and the logs, respectively. The T10%(°C) was reduced by 30°C and 10°C for the plates and the logs, respectively. The higher CO oxidation activity in the second run was due to an increase in crystallinity and the removal of adsorbed species hindering the adsorption of CO and/or oxygen [7]. In the second run, the CO oxidation activity for the plates was reduced significantly by 50°C compared to that of the logs. For the plates, the CO conversion was increased dramatically upon the initiation of CO oxidation and reached almost 100% at approximately 150°C. For the logs, the CO oxidation (%) did not increase gradually with temperature and 100% conversion was observed at approximately 400°C. As discussed above (in HRTEM and XPS), the {112} facet-exposed plates showed more active Co3+ on the surface compared to the logs. In the present study, the nanoplates showed much higher CO oxidation activity, which is in good agreement with the literature [6]. The surface area (27.7m2/g) of the nanoplates was smaller than that (31.5m2/g) of the nanologs. This suggests that the exposed crystal facet is more important than the surface area, which is in good agreement with the literature [6]. The catalytic activity could be increased by forming a metal-oxide interface [61]. CO oxidation was tested for the Ag-loaded nanoplates and nanologs, which was prepared using a photoreduction method. The Ag-loading was confirmed by SEM and XPS (Supporting information., Fig. S8 and S9). The Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2 XPS peaks were observed at 368.5 and 374.3eV, respectively, with a spin-orbit coupling of 5.9eV. This was attributed to metallic Ag [58,62]. Metallic Ag is known to be commonly formed by a photoreduction of Ag+ ion. It is also useful to use the Auger Ag MVV signal to distinguish Ag0 and Ag+ [63–65]. However, the Auger signal in the XPS was undetectable because of low (1mol%) Ag loading concentration (Supporting information., Fig. S10). For Ag2O powder, the Ag MVV Auger peak was observed at 1137.0eV. The Ag 3d5/2 XPS peak was observed at 368.8eV, which was 0.3eV higher than that of Ag-loaded Co3O4. This could reflect that the Ag in the Ag-loaded sample was metallic. Auger spectroscopy was also employed to obtain the Ag MVV signal (Supporting information., Fig. S11). The observed Auger signal was extremely weak, but detectable. The Auger peak position was more close to that of metallic Ag [65]. The Co 2p XPS peak showed no discernible BE change before and after the Ag-loading. Ag was not detected in the XRD results for the Ag-loaded samples, due to the extremely small amounts and/or low crystallinity (Supporting information., Fig. S12). For the first run of the plates loaded with Ag, the CO oxidation initiated at 220°C, which was significantly higher than that (70°C) observed for the plates. T10%(°C) was observed at 235°C and 200°C in the first and second runs, respectively. The active Co3+ sites appear to have been blocked by Ag and the adsorption of CO was hindered. Interestingly, the Ag-loaded logs showed a drastic increase in CO oxidation activity. The onset of oxidation appeared at 70°C and the T10%(°C) was observed at approximately 70°C. Upon the Ag-loading on the logs, more active sites appeared to be created to increase the CO oxidation activity. As preliminary tests, a range of metals (Au, Ag, Ni, Cu, Fe, and In) were loaded onto the Co3O4 logs by a physical (e.g., metal ion addition followed by drying) method and the CO oxidation activities were tested (Supporting information., Fig. S13, S14 and S15). The Ag-loading increased the activity, whereas the other metals degraded the activity. Zhou et al. prepared Cu(II)-substituted Co3O4 nanowires and reported increased CO oxidation activity, which was attributed to an increase in the number of oxygen vacancies by forming Co3+ OCu2+ bonds [27]. 3.5 Preferential oxidation of CO in H2-rich condition The preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) under H2-rich conditions was performed to evaluate the performance of a catalyst for residual CO removal (or H2 purification) [33]. Fig. 6 shows the CO-PROX reaction profiles for the nanoplates and nanologs. CO2 and H2O species were detected mainly in the reaction products. The other reaction products were not clearly observed. For the nanoplates, CO oxidation started at approximately 80°C. The onset temperature of H2O formation was observed at approximately 170°C. CO was oxidized preferentially, much earlier than H2 oxidation to H2O. At 170°C, 75% of CO conversion was achieved without H2 oxidation. For the nanologs, the onset of CO oxidation was observed at 100°C and H2 oxidation (or H2O formation) began to appear at 180°C. At the temperature of H2 oxidation, 54% CO conversion was achieved. Compared to the logs, the plates showed preferential CO oxidation activity and a lower CO oxidation temperature, i.e., the plates are a superior PROX catalyst to the logs. 3.6 Water-gas shift reaction and change in crystal structure/morphology A qualitative evaluation of the plates (PWGS) and logs (LWGS) was performed as a WGS reaction (CO+H2O→CO2 +H2) catalyst. Fig. 7 displays the first and second run water-gas shift reactions for the Co3O4 nanoplates and the nanologs. For the first run of the plates, there were two stages in the reaction. The first stage only showed CO2 gas, which began to appear at 300°C and decreased at 420°C. This could be due to the association between CO(g) and adsorbed oxygen. The second stage showed CO2 and H2, which were produced from 420°C. The reaction mechanism in the second stage could be explained by a well-known WGS reaction mechanism; H2Oad →Had +OHad (dissociative adsorption), COad +OHad →CO2(g)+Had (association and adsorption), Had +Had →H2(g) (associative desorption). Interestingly, in the second stage, the H2 and CO2 profiles were dissimilar between 420 and 520°C, but were similar above 520°C. This implies that the source of oxygen for the formation of CO2 between 420 and 520°C was not purely from H2O. The oxygen in the bulk Co3O4 appeared to be consumed in the reaction. In other words, Co3O4 could be reduced to CoO or Co, which will be discussed below. In the second run, the mass profiles were different. This is because the sample in the second run already experienced a temperature up to 600°C and WGS reaction environment. Only a one stage reaction was observed, where H2 and CO2 were produced simultaneously. The typical WGS reaction onset started at 350°C. For the WGS reaction of the logs, the mass profiles were similar to those of the plates. The only difference was the reaction onset. In the second run, the onset of the WGS reaction was observed at 400°C, which was 50°C higher than that (350°C) observed for the plates. Based on these results, it could be concluded that the {112}-facet exposed plate showed enhanced activity for the WGS reaction. The morphology and crystal structure of the plates and logs were examined after the WGS reaction. Fig. 8 presents the SEM images and XRD patterns. Upon the WGS reactions, the XRD patterns were changed considerably and matched those of metallic Co with a cubic (Fm-3m) crystal phase (JCPDS 98-005-3805). The major peaks were found at 2θ=44.2°, 51.5° and 75.9°, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes, respectively. Co3O4 was found to be reduced completely to metallic Co after the WGS reaction. The morphology of the plates and the logs changed distinctly after the WGS reaction. The two samples similarly showed the assembly of small (100∼200nm) grain particles. The reduction of Co oxide could be due to the generation of H2 during the WGS reaction. Hydrogen evolution and reduction were also found to be dependent on the metal-loading (Supporting information., Fig. S16 and S17). 3.7 Reduction of Co3O4 nanostructures The reduction properties were examined by hydrogen temperature programmed reduction (TPR). Fig. 9 presents the H2-TPR profiles of Co3O4 nanoplates and nanologs (Pan and Lan). Two broad reduction peaks were commonly observed at 440°C and 560°C, which were attributed to two-step wise reductions of the oxides: 1st step, Co3O4 +H2 →3CoO+H2O; and 2nd step, CoO+H2 →Co+H2O [21,37,66]. The Co3+ in Co3O4 (where Co=2+ and 3+) is initially reduced to Co2+ at 440°C, which is reduced further to metallic Co at a higher temperature of 560°C. The hydrogen consumption ratio of the two peaks is close the theoretical value of approximately 1:3. The onset of the TPR peak for the nanoplates was observed at a lower temperature than that for the nanologs. This suggests that more active Co3+ is present on the surface of the nanoplates. The SEM image taken after the TPR changed significantly due to a change in the crystal phase from Co3O4 to Co. The morphology of the CO3O4 after TPR was examined by SEM (Supporting information, Fig. S18). The morphology was changed significantly due to a change in the crystal phase, as observed for the samples (Fig. 8) after the WGS reaction. 3.8 Characterization of the samples after the catalytic reactions The samples after the above catalytic reactions were further examined by XRD, SEM/TEM and XPS. After CO oxidation, the cubic crystal phase of the CO3O4 was not critically changed based on the XRD patterns (Supporting information., Fig. 19). The SEM and TEM images showed that the morphologies of the corresponding samples were not changed much although the surface roughness was somewhat changed. (Supporting information., Fig. S20 and S21). However, after the WGSR and CO-PROX reactions the morphologies of the catalysts were found to be significantly changed (Supporting information., Fig. 21). The plate morphology was changed to micron-size aggregated particles after WGSR. After CO-PROX, some aggregated nanoparticles were observed on the plates. The significant change in morphology could reflect a change in crystal structure (or oxidation state). It was already discussed that Co3O4 changed to metallic Co after WGSR, based on the corresponding XRD patterns (Fig. 8). XPS (Fig. 10 ) was employed to further characterize the samples after the catalytic reactions. After CO oxidation, the Co 2p showed no change, indication of stable oxidation state before and after the reaction (Supporting information., Fig. 22). After CO-PROX, the Co 2p peak of Co2+ and the corresponding shake-up peak were enhanced after the reaction. This indicates that CoO species were formed on the surface. The Ag 3d5/2 peaks were found at 368.5 and 368.1eV after CO oxidation and CO-PROX, respectively (Supporting information., Fig. 23). The binding energy (BE) of Ag 3d5/2 was shifted by −0.4eV after CO-PROX although the BE of Ag 3d showed no change after CO oxidation. The metallic Ag showed more reduced character after CO-PROX. After WGSR, the Co 2p peak showed a more drastic change. A new Co 2p3/2 peak at 778.3eV was observed, attributed to metallic Co, in good consistent with the XRD result (Fig. 8). The Co 2p3/2 peak at 780.7eV was attributed to CoO by surface oxidation of metallic Co. Stability of a catalyst is very important for industrial application. The amount surface carbon was not critically changed after CO oxidation and CO-PROX (Supporting information., Fig. 23). Especially after CO oxidation, the oxidation state showed no change. This indicates that the catalysts were stable. However, the surface carbon was dramatically increased and the oxidation state was critically changed after WGSR indicating that the Co3O4 catalyst was unstable for WGSR. 3.9 Electrochemical properties and supercapacitor performance The electrochemical properties were examined and the results are displayed in Fig. 11 . The cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were obtained between −0.2V and 0.7V at different scan rates, 5, 10, 20, 40, 60, 80, and 100mV/s. The CV curves showed good cyclic behavior. The peak currents generally increased with increasing scan rate and the oxidation/reduction peak positions were shifted gradually with changing rates. This indicates a diffusion-controlled electrode reaction and a good reversible charge-discharge process [9]. Two cathodic and two anodic peaks were observed, and the peak positions were somewhat different for the plates and the logs. The two peaks were understood by two-step electrochemical redox processes via the conversion of Co(II)↔Co(III) and Co(III)↔Co(IV). The two redox electrochemical reactions are generally written as follows [13,17,29]. Co3O4 +OH− +H2O↔3CoOOH+e− CoOOH+OH− ↔CoO2 +H2O+e− The galvanostatic charge-discharge curves were obtained for the plates and logs. The charge-discharge time increased with increasing current density, as expected. At a fixed current density, the discharge time of the plates was much (2×) longer than that of the logs. The specific capacitance (Cm, F/g) was calculated using Cm =(I·Dt)/(ΔV·m), where Δt is the discharge time (sec), ΔV is the potential range, Cm (Fg−1) is the specific capacitance, and m is the mass of the loaded sample [67,68]. I is the discharge current (A). At a current density of 1.25/g, the specific capacitance of the plates was calculated to be 123F/g, which was 2× larger than that of the logs. This suggests that the {112} exposed facet for the plates is feasible for ion transport. Wang et al. synthesized Co3O4 nanomesh (a surface area of 382m2/g) with a dominant (-112) facet and reported capacitances of 152–298F/g in a 3M KOH solution. The value was higher than those (∼20F/g) observed for the materials with {111} and {100} facets [50]. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to examine the impedance. The typical Nyquist plots show the real (Z′) and imaginary (Z″) parts of the impedance. The real (Z′) part increased with decreasing frequency. The plots for the plates and the logs commonly showed a semicircle in the high-frequency region and a straight line in the low frequency region, which was attributed to interface (electrode/electrolyte) charge transfer and the OH− diffusion resistance (or Warburg impedance), respectively [14,17,47]. The semicircle for the plates was smaller than that for the logs, indicating lower interfacial resistance in the electrochemical reaction. The solution/charge transfer resistances for the logs and the plates were measured to be 0.8Ω and 1.4Ω, respectively. The lower resistance may be responsible for the high charge storage [67]. 4 Conclusions Cubic phase Co3O4 nanoplates and nanologs were prepared by post-thermal annealing of the as-prepared hexagonal Co(OH)2 nanoplates and monoclinic cobalt oxalate dihydrate, C2CoO4∙2H2O nanologs, respectively. The nanoplates had more exposed {112} facets than the nanologs. The facet appeared to have more active Co3+ based on XPS and HRTEM. This commonly resulted in much higher performance for CO oxidation, preferential CO oxidation in H2-rich condition, WGS reaction, as well as supercapacitor performance. The CO oxidation (T10% =100°C) activity of the nanoplates was higher than that (T10% =150°C) of the logs. Upon Ag-modification, the CO oxidation activity of the nanoplates was decreased dramatically, whereas the activity of the nanologs increased significantly. For the preferential oxidation of CO under H2-rich conditions, the nanoplates achieved 75% of CO conversion at the onset temperature of H2 oxidation, whereas the logs only achieved 54% CO conversion. The onset of the WGS reaction for the nanoplates was observed at 350°C, whereas that of the logs appeared at 400°C. Upon WGS reaction, Co3O4 was reduced to metallic Co, as evidenced by XRD. The specific capacitance (123F/g) of the nanoplates was 2× times higher than that of the nanologs. The present study revealed a better strategy for the development of Co-based materials by testing the wider applications and designing the morphology. coredata.dc:description: Tailoring the exposed crystal facet of a material is a very important strategy for improving the application performance. Herein, cubic phase Co3O4 with two different morphologies, nanoplates and nanologs, was synthesized, and CO oxidation, preferential oxidation of CO (CO-PROX) under H2-rich condition, water-gas shift (WGS) reaction, and supercapacitor properties were examined. The nanoplates with {112}-exposed facets showed better performance in all the test model systems. The {112} facets contained more active Co3+, which is responsible for the activation of CO oxidation (and H2 production) at a lower temperatures. A facial ion transport on the facet increased the specific capacitance of the plates. The wider application tests and the design of Co oxide nanostructures provide a better strategy for the development of Co-based materials.
coredata.dc:title: Crystal-facet dependent CO oxidation, preferential oxidation of CO in H2-rich, water-gas shift reactions, and supercapacitor application over Co3O4 nanostructures
